title-group.article-title: Patient and Public Involvement in the Coproduction of Knowledge
title-group.subtitle: Reflection on the Analysis of Qualitative Data in a Mental Health Study

article-meta.aff: 1St George’s, University of London, London, United Kingdom

author-notes.corresp: Steve Gillard, Section of Mental Health, St George’s, University of London, Cranmer Terrace, London SW17 0RE, UK Email: sgillard@sgul.ac.uk

abstract.p: Patient and public involvement in health research is increasingly well established internationally, but the impacts of involvement on the research process are hard to evaluate. We describe a process of qualitative data analysis in a mental health research project with a high level of mental health service user and carer involvement, and reflect critically on how we produced our findings. Team members not from research backgrounds sometimes challenged academic conventions, leading to complex findings that would otherwise have been missing. An essential component of how we coproduced knowledge involved retaining methodological flexibility so that nonconventional research voices in the team could situate and critique what was conventionally known. Deliberate and transparent reflection on how “who we are” informed the knowledge we produced was integral to our inquiry. We conclude that reflecting on knowledge (co)production is a useful tool for evaluating the impact of patient and public involvement on health research.

body.p: Patient and public involvement in health care research has become increasingly common internationally (Holmes, Stewart, Garrow, Anderson, & Thorpe, 2002; Mosavel, Simon, van Stade, & Buchbinder, 2005; Schneider et al., 2004) and is now a requirement in most publically funded research in the United Kingdom (Department of Health, 2006). The recent history of active involvement in the research process of people who use health and social care services is well documented and has begun to be systematically evaluated (Staley, 2009). The involvement of mental health service users in research has been particularly well described (Sweeney, Beresford, Faulkner, Nettle, & Rose, 2009).

It has been argued that, given the expertise that people experiencing mental health problems have in managing their lives (Faulkner & Layzell, 2000), building an evidence base for mental health services should be conducted as a marriage of expertise by experience and expertise by profession (Faulkner & Thomas, 2002). The difficulties of assessing the epistemological impact on the research process of involving service users have been acknowledged (Smith et al., 2008; Staley, 2009). Without this insight, the knowledge claims of research involving patients and the public (Beresford, 2005; Simpson & House, 2002) remain hard to assess. The potential for that research to improve health care practice is constrained as a result, especially when strict hierarchies prevail about what constitutes good scientific evidence.

A small, qualitative study of organizational change in a United Kingdom mental health service organization undertaken by some of the authors identified impacts on the design of the study and on the processes of data collection and data analysis resulting from involvement of mental health service users as members of the research team (Gillard, Turner, et al., 2010). In addition, a reflexive process undertaken by the team suggested that service user involvement not only had added “expertise by experience” to the research process but also to some extent had changed the process. Some of the academic conventions of doing research about mental health had been challenged, and there was something different about the way the research had been done as a result.

Recent thinking about science and society has labeled this different way of doing research as the “coproduction” of knowledge, a blurring of the boundaries between scientific practitioners and those on the receiving end of scientific enquiry (Nowotny, Scott, & Gibbons, 2001). A move away from conventional scientific research, led by a single academic discipline based within a university department, toward a model that involves a range of scientific and nonscientific expertise—an “expert laity”—has been noted (Gibbons et al., 1994). This new means of coproducing scientific knowledge has been characterized as
transdisciplinary rather than mono- or multidisciplinary. It is carried out in nonhierarchical, heterogeneously organized forms which are essentially transient. It is not being institutionalized primarily within university structures. [It] involves the close interaction of many actors throughout the process of knowledge production and this means that knowledge production is becoming more socially accountable. . . . Overall, the process of knowledge production is becoming more reflexive and affects at the deepest levels what shall count as “good science.” (Gibbons et al., p. vi)

Coproduction has some clear similarity to participatory action research (PAR) or community-based participatory research (CBPR; Mosavel et al., 2005), especially in the way trust, collaboration, shared decision making, and shared ownership of the research across the range of stakeholders are sought. An important distinction is that PAR/CBPR strives to produce action and change as an integral part of the research process. In the research project considered here—commissioned through the university sector—the more traditional academic approach of producing new knowledge was the end point of the process.

The integration of different episteme in the production of knowledge about health has been documented. For example, health care practitioners have been shown to integrate scientific, evidence-based knowledge with other types of knowledge to inform their practice (James, Andershed, Gustavsson, & Ternestedt, 2010), and mental health researchers have described a reflexive process of collectively constructing knowledge as a methodological solution to analyzing qualitative interviews when the face validity of the data is hard to establish (Patterson, Hart, & Weaver, 2010).

In this article, we reflect critically on a systematically documented process of data analysis to describe the way knowledge was produced through that process, and to consider who produced that knowledge. We examine a mental health research project that had a high level of involvement of people with personal experience of mental health issues, of using mental health services, or of caring for someone with mental health issues, alongside clinical and conventional university researchers. The aims of the research project were to investigate ways in which United Kingdom mental health service organizations were supporting people to care for their own mental health (Gillard, Edwards, et al., 2010).

We focus exclusively on describing and reflecting on the process of analyzing data, which is a key site of knowledge production in qualitative research. The detailed processes of reporting qualitative analysis are often lacking in research articles, in part because the complex, messy, and often intuitive tasks involved do not always sit easily with the academic conventions required of clean retrospective reporting (Simons, Lathlean, & Squire, 2008). In the study, we adopted a team approach to qualitative analysis that necessitated a detailed documentary record of the analytical decisions made. We use this documentary record to track and articulate the extent to which the team engaged in knowledge coproduction, from preliminary analyses conducted early in the study through to the writing up of findings and recommendations published in the final report.

sec.title: Aim
sec.p: In this article we aim to (a) describe the team process of qualitative data analysis undertaken in a study of support for self-care in mental health in the United Kingdom, (b) reflect on the extent to which we coproduced knowledge through the qualitative analysis process as a research team with a high level of patient and public involvement, and (c) consider the implications of research coproduction for study findings. In the discussion of our analysis process, we also consider whether the concept of research coproduction offers a tool for considering the impact of service user and carer involvement in mental health services research.

sec.title: The Team
sec.p: Our research team of 17 individuals comprised health service researchers (n = 6), a human resource management researcher, service user (patient) and carer (family or friend caregiver) researchers (n = 7), clinicians (n = 4), and National Health Service (NHS; U.K. statutory health service) managers (n = 2). Some members of the team had more than one role and have been counted in each relevant category; one of the carer researchers was also a clinician, one of the clinicians was also a manager in the NHS, and one of the managers was also a health services researcher. All service user and carer researchers had first-degree-level education, but only two service user researchers had experience of research outside of the context of completing an undergraduate degree. Some service user researchers were still receiving formal care and treatment for mental health issues. Two of the clinicians had little experience of research prior to their involvement in this project.

The study was initially led by the university members of the team, with support from clinical and managerial members of the team. The role of the latter group was to ensure the research reflected priorities of health service delivery and to facilitate access to health service sites. Two service user researchers were involved in the team from the outset, developing the proposal and supporting the involvement of other service user and carer researchers. One was already employed as a researcher in a university, and the other as a researcher and trainer in the NHS. Five service user and carer researchers, who undertook the data collection and much of the analysis at each of the three study sites, were recruited to their positions through open employment recruitment and selection processes. Personal experience of mental health issues or of caring for someone with personal experience of mental health issues and some prior research experience were stipulated as essential criteria for applicants to these posts. These researchers were employed by the relevant university or health service provider organization, giving them full access to organizational facilities and staff development opportunities. Bespoke training on research interviewing and data analysis was given by other members of the research team and external providers as required.

Frequent, usually weekly, meetings were held in each study site where the service user and carer researchers were supervised by the site lead. Five whole-team meetings took place throughout the study, with communications and discussions taking place by teleconference and email between meetings. One service user researcher left the project after 15 months and was replaced, again through an open recruitment process. Continuity was promoted at this site because another service user researcher remained in post throughout.

sec.title: The Study: Supporting Self-Care in Mental Health
sec.p: We employed a mixed-methods cohort study design in this study. A total of 120 new users of a range of adult mental health services supporting self-care at three case study sites undertook qualitative and quantitative interviews, both when they started using the service and again 9 months later. Participants’ expectations and understandings of self-care were explored in qualitative interviews at baseline. Their experiences of the self-care support service were explored in follow-up interviews 9 months later. Quantitative data collected at baseline and follow-up included sociodemographics and psychiatric history, service use, and a range of standardized measures of psychosocial outcome. Participants’ informal carers, managers, and staff working in the self-care support services also undertook qualitative interviews about their views and experiences.

sec.title: Method of Analysis
sec.p: In the self-care study, qualitative analysis proceeded through a number of stages, as illustrated in Figure 1. Early stages of the process were repeated as each data set (service user, carer, and staff interviews) was collected. We describe each stage of the analysis process in detail below and illustrate the process with examples of analytical material generated during the process.

caption.p: Flow chart of the analysis process

sec.title: Stage 1: Preliminary Analysis
sec.p: Service user and carer researchers had been involved in the process of developing semistructured interview schedules and conducted the vast majority of interviews. In carrying out interviews, they were encouraged to ask additional questions to follow lines of inquiry that seemed to be relevant to participants (see Gillard, Edwards, et al., 2010). These same researchers then undertook preliminary analyses of a subsample of interviews. Service user and carer researchers were trained together in using data coding tools common to inductive thematic analysis (Ritchie & Lewis, 2003). We used an open coding approach to organize text into categories on the basis of content of the talk in the interviews.

Service user and carer researchers were encouraged to create their own thematic categories, guided by the data, as they read and coded the text. In so doing we recognized that a layer of interpretation would inevitably begin to be imposed from researchers’ individual perspectives. To keep track of this interpretive process, researchers were directed to keep memos of decisions they made about the creation and labeling of new categories. We summarized this preliminary analysis into tables using examples from the text to illustrate each category. An example of a page from a summary document is given in Table 1, documenting one researcher’s preliminary analysis of the first section—Getting Involved—of two baseline interviews with service user participants.

sec.title: Stage 2: Developing an Analytical Framework
sec.p: At whole-team meetings, the service user and carer researchers who had undertaken the preliminary analysis presented their analyses of each successive set of interviews (e.g., service user baseline, staff) to the whole research team. We used a process of face-to-face team discussion to produce a single analytical framework, employing a modified matrix approach (Averill, 2002) to organize and compare analyses from the different sites. Prior to each meeting, we compiled preliminary analyses onto a single matrix that presented sections of the interview schedule on the horizontal axis and case study sites on the vertical axis. Each cell of the matrix was populated with a summary of the relevant preliminary analysis. At meetings we projected these matrices onto a screen to facilitate discussion. We used an additional row on the matrix to record the discussion as it took place, with members of the team offering their individual interpretations of the data as they were presented. When we offered different interpretations, we considered in our discussion why different members of the team understood the data differently. Through this process we developed and refined, as a team, an inclusive set of themes that enabled us to (a) integrate the analyses from each site and (b) capture the interpretive perspectives of all members of the team. This work was undertaken by the lead author (a health services researcher) and by service user and carer researchers. We circulated drafts of the framework across the team to ensure that idiosyncrasies of data at all sites were captured. Examples of themes and descriptors derived from the Getting Involved section of the service user baseline interview are given in Table 3.

sec.title: Stage 3: Applying the Analytical Framework
sec.p: We then used these themes and descriptors to code all interviews in each qualitative data set, building up a comprehensive database of coded text. Again, the vast majority of this work was undertaken by service user and carer researchers. When interview data did not fit comfortably into the framework, or when researchers were unsure how to code data, we resolved issues and modified the framework through team discussion (facilitated by email in between meetings). These discussions became an important part of the analysis process. An example of this process of clarifying and modifying themes and their descriptors is given in Table 4.

sec.title: Stage 4: Stakeholder Conferences
sec.p: Toward the end of the project we presented our emerging analysis to groups of stakeholders at each of the case study sites. Participants comprised a total of 28 service users, 4 carers, 25 clinical staff, and 14 managers of mental health services. Participants included people who had taken part in the main study as well as others invited because they were involved in other similar interventions in their mental health service organizations (e.g., self-management programs, supported employment projects). Carers were partners of service users who attended with them. Clinicians included community mental health service staff, employment specialists, and psychological therapists. Managers included senior strategic managers, human resource managers, and managers of clinical services. We used structured group discussions to enable participants to discuss the relevance of each of the themes in terms of their own personal experience. Participants highlighted a number of issues as particularly relevant and offered interpretations of some issues that had not been in the forefront of our analyses. sec.title: Stage 5: Asking Questions of the Qualitative Data
sec.p: The application of the analytical framework described above represented a first-level analysis in which we aimed primarily to organize the data to facilitate a deeper analysis (Mason, 1996). Issues we identified at the feedback conference helped inform a series of specific questions we asked of the qualitative data set using the “query” function of the qualitative data analysis software. We generated additional queries through a process of synthesizing qualitative and quantitative analyses. When we found associations to be statistically significant in the quantitative data set, for example between particular participant characteristics and changes in outcome, those individual participant characteristics were assigned to interview transcripts in the database. We then ran queries that enabled us to compare qualitative data coded to relevant themes (e.g., Changes in Care) between particular groups of participants (e.g., participants who chose whether or not to take medication as prescribed). sec.p: Various members of the research team (including the lead researcher, and service user and carer researchers) then wrote “query reports” based on each query. In these reports we organized data in terms of specified axes of comparison (e.g., case study site, clinical severity of participants at baseline). We wrote narratives that sought to find meaning in commonalities and differences between comparison groups.

sec.title: Stage 6: Writing Up the Research
sec.p: Through the process described above, we generated a “library” of query reports that we used as a resource to write sections of the final report. Once again, we assigned writing tasks to various members of the team. Drafted sections were then circulated to the whole team, going through a number of iterative revisions in the process. It has been noted that writing is a stage in the process of qualitative inquiry in its own right, that the act of writing makes things known to the researcher that would not otherwise have been known (Richardson, 2000). As such, we were concerned that our writing should continue to give voice to the range of interpretive perspectives within the team, even as that writing became the responsibility of a smaller number of individuals. We reflect on tensions that arose at the final writing-up stage of the process in some depth in the discussion section below.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The detailed documentation of our analysis process has enabled us to describe in depth the involvement of different members of the team, including service user and carer researchers, in the research process (Aim 1). This provides us with an opportunity to consider the extent to which knowledge was coproduced in our research (Aim 2). In the introduction we offered a working definition of research coproduction characterized by

list-item.p: a move away from academically led research institutionalized within the university
a transdisciplinary approach involving a range of scientific and nonscientific expertise
nonhierarchical, heterogeneously organized forms of undertaking research
an increasing reflexivity and social accountability of knowledge production
a challenge to what is counted as “good science” (Gibbons et al., 1994; Nowotny et al., 2001)

sec.p: In this discussion we adopt a “radical reflexive approach” (Cunliffe, 2003) to consider the extent to which our research was coproduced. We borrow this approach from a qualitative study about United Kingdom local government chief executives in which Orr and Bennett (2009) considered the extent to which, as academic and practitioner, they jointly constituted the knowledge that emerged from the research, as opposed to a more simplistic production of an academic monologue. Where there is evidence that our work demonstrates these characteristics of coproduction, we also consider how the coproduction process has affected the study’s findings and recommendations (Aim 3). Finally, we consider the extent to which research coproduction offers a conceptual tool to evaluate the impact of service user and carer involvement on mental health services research.

sec.title: How Were Service User and Carer Researchers Involved in the Research?
sec.p: We illustrate the mechanics of service user and carer researcher involvement in our description of the process of generating an analytical framework from our interview transcripts (Stages 1 to 3). Service user and carer researchers were integral to the decision-making process about coding interview data alongside other members of the team; we also briefly indicated the role played by service user and carer researchers in developing and undertaking interviews. Service user and carer researchers often led on generating analytical categories and presenting these to the team for discussion and refinement. The creation of an additional Staff Attitudes category to preserve the distinctiveness of data capturing service user participants’ Personal Philosophies—Table 4—was an example of the growing confidence demonstrated by service user and carer researchers to make research decisions as the project progressed.

Researchers were at times concerned about the impact their personal interpretive perspectives might be having on the analytical decision-making process. We used repeated cycles of going back to the team to remain aware of this possibility but were also careful not to use the team to reduce analysis to an exercise in interrater reliability. Conventionally, much clinical research uses “triangulation by perspective” (Patton, 1990). Such an approach would have limited the production of knowledge to that which we could all reliably agree on. Instead, the range of perspectives in the team enabled us to elicit different possible interpretations of the data and to explore the particular validity of all interpretations by reflecting on the analytical lens—of health services researcher, clinician, service user, and so on—through which the interpretation was made (Mason, 1996).

For example, in our initial analyses of data coded under Getting Involved (Tables 1-3), we identified self-referral into support services as an important issue for research participants. Service user, carer, and clinical and organizational researchers all offered different perspectives on these data. The process of integrating, through team discussion, a range of perspectives enabled us to move beyond a simplistic analysis (see discussion of impact on findings below).

We were also able to invite other nonconventional research voices into the knowledge production process through our feedback conferences (Stage 4). Participants in those conferences—including service users and carers—flagged the importance of a range of issues that had not been prominent in our emerging analysis. For example, as a result of the feedback conferences, we revisited our data to make sure we acknowledged the ambivalence to self-care that some participants expressed. This ambivalence included both the sense of abandonment some service users associated with what they experienced as being discharged from supportive services to self-care and the risk of creating new sites of dependence where peer groups successfully created a strong sense of identity (Table 5).

sec.title: To What Extent Did We Coproduce Knowledge in Our Research?
sec.p: We described above our integration of different interpretive perspectives in the research team to create a more nuanced picture of self-care. Sometimes this process fostered tensions within the team, particularly in the later writing-up stages (Stages 5 and 6). These tensions are particularly well illustrated in the writing up of findings around the relationship between psychiatric medication and self-care (see Table 6). Medication had not emerged as an important theme in the qualitative analysis, but the parallel quantitative analysis had revealed a number of statistically significant associations between medication (including whether or not participants chose to take their medication as prescribed) and changes in outcome measures (see Table 6).

As a team we were able to offer a range of explanations for these different associations but were unable to agree on the importance of them. Some members of the team, especially service user researchers, insisted that even though these findings might be statistically significant, we had produced them only because, at the outset of the project, the university researchers had decided to ask structured, quantifiable questions about medication. The health services researchers on the team countered that, because the findings were there, we were duty bound to report them. On this issue in particular, the team discussion became very heated, although always focused on issues related to the data. The service user researchers asserted that simply accepting academic conventions would compromise both what they thought they had been told by participants during interviews and the trust and partnership developed thus far in the team. Finding a way through this tension felt very uncomfortable at times, and we eventually agreed to return to the qualitative data to explore the issue of medication in more depth.

We ran queries on the qualitative data set using qualitative analysis computer software that enabled us to compare medication accounts between groups of service users who reported choosing to take their medication as prescribed with those who had chosen not to. Through this analysis we revealed a complex set of experiences with and attitudes toward taking medication, its benefits and negative impacts on people’s lives, and the relationship of medication to self-care. Our writing up became an exercise in articulating tensions in the analysis as a means of trying to understand the complex relationship between self-care and medication.

The prominence of these findings related to medication had taken us all by surprise as none of the case study interventions had focused on medication. When the importance of medication findings was questioned, we were able to reflect on the “social accountability” of decisions we made about how to do the research (Gibbons et al., 1994). We had produced these findings because the structured questions we asked about medication were the sorts of questions that university researchers on the team routinely used in clinical studies. These studies had been positively peer reviewed by other academics. We noted the lack of coproduction—and involvement of service user and carer researchers—at the early stages of developing the funding bid for this research when these questions were included, uncritically, in the research protocol.

We had followed conventions of statistical analysis until a number of team members, primarily service user researchers, had strongly challenged the assumption that statistical significance meant that findings about medication were necessarily of such importance that they should dominate the study’s conclusions. In other words, what university members of the research team had seen at the study’s inception to “count as good science” (Gibbons et al., 1994) was challenged from perspectives outside of the conventional team. The impact of this process of challenging research conventions on our findings is considered below.

sec.title: How Did Coproduction Affect Research Findings?
sec.p: Our reflection on the process of coproduction described above allows us to consider the impact of that process on research findings. For example, in our coproduced analysis of interview data concerning self-referral, different members of the team offered and advocated for the importance of different possible interpretations of the data. We noted professional “gatekeeping” of self-referral—wherein professionals’ protective attitudes to risk management determined who was allowed to “self-refer”—and also how service user participants were concerned with the safety of groups that were wholly open access. Our discussions foregrounded the recognition by clinicians, managers, and carers of the sense of empowerment experienced by service users who were exercising control over when and how they accessed services, as well as acknowledging the challenges that that presented to caring relationships.

This integrative approach to analysis enabled us to move beyond simplistic juxtaposition of service user accounts of being allowed or denied choice with clinician accounts of risk management. As a result, we made recommendations in our final report (Gillard, Edwards, et al., 2010) that added to ongoing debates about positive risk taking (Morgan, 2000), self-referral (Rogers, Oliver, Bower, Lovell, & Richards, 2004), and punitive discharge (Lester, Tritter, & Sorohan, 2005) in mental health services.

The tensions noted in the team around integrating quantitative and qualitative analyses very directly affected the findings we produced. Our revisiting of the qualitative data around medication revealed an additional layer of interpretation that would otherwise have been missing from our findings. We found that service user participants who felt supported clinically made decisions either to take medication as prescribed or to come off medication as an important aspect of their self-care (compared to other participants who were still struggling with whether to take medication or not). Complex and subtle findings emerged about relationships between the service user and clinician, medication, choice, and self-care. Recommendations we made in our final report added to ongoing debate around medication and shared decision making (Deegan & Drake, 2006; Schauer, Everett, del Vecchio, & Anderson, 2007), and concordance and adherence (Horne et al., 2005).

The broader literature on research coproduction suggests that sustainable change and translation of knowledge into practice is more likely when coproduction between practitioners and academics has taken place (Baumbusch et al., 2008; Hall, 2006). In the health service management field, knowledge coproduction has been shown to close a relevance gap between research and practice (Starkey & Madan, 2001). The potential benefits of involving users of health services in writing up research—more hard-hitting and user-friendly reporting—have been noted (McLaughlin, 2006; Sutton & Weiss, 2008). However, a general lack of involvement of service user researchers in the writing up stage has also been identified (Smith et al., 2008).

In our case, the conventional, economically driven practice of disbanding a university-based research team once the funding has run its course and the final report to sponsors has been written did not work to our advantage. Even though we noted above the extent to which writing as an integral part of the analysis process during the project worked to realize and articulate coproduction in the research process, we were equally challenged by the drop off of coproduction as the research came to a close and the wider team disbanded.

For example, to complete the conventional medical school research cycle, it was necessary for the university members of the team to submit our main findings for publication in a high-impact medical journal. This required us to follow the detailed and exacting guidelines for the reporting of observational studies, Strengthening The Reporting of OBservational studies in Epidemiology (STROBE; von Elm et al., 2007), and in so doing our painstaking qualitative analyses were reduced to the status of “other analyses” used to explore subgroups and confounders emerging in the statistical analysis. In fulfilling these requirements we lacked the space, methodologically as well as in terms of word count, both to articulate the subtlety of our coproduced findings and to report reflectively on how those findings were the product of the particular identities and perspectives of different members of the research team.

We were in danger of rewriting, or reproducing our research as an academic monologue as a result (Orr & Bennett, 2009), distilling the additional layers of meaning we had so carefully worked to uncover and articulate. Other ways and means of writing up and disseminating research can be pursued, but the university requires its researchers to prioritize high-impact, peer-reviewed output. We think that this challenge to knowledge coproduction in health services research remains unresolved and largely unexplored.

sec.title: Considering the Impact of Service User and Carer Involvement on Research
sec.p: We began this discussion by presenting a generic definition of knowledge coproduction. We have shown above how coproduction in our research took on a particular form, shaped by the specifics of the project; a mental health services research project that introduced high levels of service user and carer involvement into an otherwise reasonably conventional, multidisciplinary clinical–academic research team. Coproduction of knowledge in our study was characterized as follows:

list-item.p: High-value research decision-making roles were distributed across a research team including university, clinical, service user, carer, and managerial researchers.

Different interpretations of data within the research team were owned and understood in terms of who offered the interpretation; proper consideration was given to the question of how who we are has shaped the knowledge we have produced.

Consideration was given to whether all members of the team were involved in the production of knowledge throughout the research project; when there was unevenness in the coproduction of knowledge, the impact of this was considered.
Methodological flexibility was allowed in the research process when the scientific conventions of how research is usually done in the university constrained the input of particular team members.
Rigorous and critical reflection on why the research was done in the way it was (rather than just a rigorous application of scientific method) was integral to the conduct of the research.
Research outputs were attempted that reported critically on how knowledge was produced so readers of the research would be able to understand how findings were shaped by those involved.

sec.p: We suggest here that it is a self-conscious and explicit reflection on the process of knowledge coproduction, as described above, that in itself offers a conceptual tool for considering the impact of service user and carer involvement in mental health services research. Specifically, this means reflecting on the involvement of all members of the research team in the process of knowledge production, and not singling out the involvement of service user and carer researchers as a “radical” addition to a conventional academic team. Service user knowledge, or more specifically “survivor-produced knowledge,” has been described as a radical alternative to medically produced knowledge (Rose, 2009). The limitations of seeing specific sites of knowledge production as radical have been noted in the past by critical epistemologists who have argued that knowledge produced from any one particular standpoint cannot exist autonomously from other knowledge in the same referential frame (Harding, 1991); any knowledge can only be understood in relation to those other standpoints around it (Keller, 1984).

Our study shows how the power of service user and carer produced knowledge did not lie in its refuting of medically or academically produced knowledge, but in the opportunity it offered to situate and critique that more dominant discourse. The presence of service user and carer voices in the mental health research team did not oblige us to choose between alternative perspectives as more or less valid than each other, or that we should understand them as separate, irreconcilable accounts. Rather, we found that those different voices provided our research team with an opportunity to begin bridging the apparent dichotomy of what was conventionally known and what was “radically” known. Our university researchers lost their exclusive status as arbiters of good science. Instead, we asked ourselves how our respective contributions to the research process were socially situated, and what that meant for the knowledge that was produced.

We wondered if “doing good science” might be about this act of critical reflection itself and that, as a deliberate and transparent process, this reflection should become an integral component of doing research. So that knowledge claims made for the research can be understood in the context of their socially situated production—who was involved in the production of knowledge—both the means and meaning of coproduction should be made available to the reader of the research, as we have attempted to do in this article.

Coproducing knowledge in mental health services research thus goes beyond adding voices to an academic monologue—the aim of some methods of patient and public involvement—and instead conceptualizes a creative process of producing new knowledge through colloquy, the exploration and articulation of what different voices mean in relation to each other. Our systematic reflection on the extent to which knowledge was coproduced, aided by a detailed documentary record of the research process, offers a conceptual tool for evaluating the impact of service user and carer researchers on our research.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In this article, we describe a team process of qualitative data analysis, using a detailed documentary record of the process to reflect on the involvement of service user and carer researchers. In our reflexive discussion, we show how we were coproducing knowledge in terms of many of the generic characteristics of coproduction (Gibbons et al., 1994; Nowotny et al., 2001). In addition, we advance a more specific understanding of knowledge coproduction in the context of mental health services research. We also illustrate how coproduction in our project directly affected research findings in a number of areas, including issues such as self-referral, positive risk taking, and shared decision making in mental health services. In doing so, we demonstrate the potential of systematic reflection on the process of knowledge coproduction—as characterized above—as a conceptually useful means of trying to understand how service user and carer involvement impacts on research. We stress that that reflection should be both integral to the research process and made explicit to the reader so he or she can make sense of how the knowledge has been produced and by whom. That critical reflection should focus on researchers from within the conventional clinical–academic research team, as much as on service user and carer researchers.

This article is limited in that we report a process of knowledge coproduction in research, in vivo, and reflect on that process retrospectively. We have necessarily not been able to test more widely the strengths and weaknesses of our particular understanding of knowledge coproduction as a tool for evaluating service user and carer involvement in mental health research. Additional research could write that prospective testing into a suitable project. Nonetheless, this article demonstrates the potential for using the concept of knowledge coproduction as a tool for considering how service user and carer involvement affects the research process and research findings.
